data: Three municipal ferries were located on the waterfront: the Peck Slip Ferry at the foot of Broadway; Grand Street ferry at the foot of Grand Street; and the 10th Street ferry at the foot of Greenpoint Avenue. Upland, Greenpoint and Williamsburg were working-class neighborhoods of mostly wood-frame tenements and row houses. Masonry buildings were less common and largely restricted to the higher elevation (and higher income) parts of the neighborhood â€“ the original Williamsbugh village between Grand Street and Broadway in the Southside; North 8th Street and Berry in the Northside; and Java to Calyer Streets in Greenpoint. At this point, the demographics were already shifting from the predominant German and Irish immigrants of the mid-19th century to Italians, Poles and other Eastern Europeans who moved to the area in large numbers starting in the 1880s and 1890s.[WD1]
